paper_title.ja: On the break interval sequences of equitable round-robin tournaments
paper_title.en: ON THE BREAK INTERVAL SEQUENCES OF EQUITABLE ROUND-ROBIN TOURNAMENTS

description.ja: We study the mathematical structure of equitable round-robin tournamentswith home-away assignments, and give some necessary conditions forthe feasibility of home-away tables, by using their friend-enemy tables andbreak interval sequences. We examine the relation of these conditions andenumerate the feasible break interval sequences. By our method, makingschedules of equitable round-robin tournaments can be reduced to determiningsome sequences of positive integers satisfying certain inequalities.

paper_title.ja: Tate and Ate pairings for y^2=x^5-αx in characteristic five
paper_title.en: Tate and ate pairings for y(2) = x(5)-alpha x in characteristic five

description.en: In this paper, we consider the Tate and Ate pairings for the genus-2 supersingular hyperelliptic curves y(2) = x(5) - alpha x (alpha = +/- 2) defined over finite fields of characteristic five. More precisely, we construct a distortion map explicitly, and show that the map indeed gives an input for which the value of the Tate pairing is not trivial. We next describe a computation of the Tate pairing by using the proposed distortion map. We also see that this type of curve is equipped with a simple quintuple operation on the Jacobian group, which leads to an improvement for computing the Tate pairing. We further show the Ate pairing, a variant of the Tate pairing for elliptic curves, can be applied to this curve. The Ate pairing yields an algorithm which is about 50 % more efficient than the Tate pairing in this case.

publication_name.ja: the Japan Journal of Industrial and Applied Mathematics
publication_name.en: JAPAN JOURNAL OF INDUSTRIAL AND APPLIED MATHEMATICS

paper_title.en: Tate and Ate pairings for y2 = x5 - αx in characteristic five

description.en: In this paper, we consider the Tate and Ate pairings for the genus-2 supersingular hyperelliptic curves y2 = x5 - αx (α = ±2) defined over finite fields of characteristic five. More precisely, we construct a distortion map explicitly, and show that the map indeed gives an input for which the value of the Tate pairing is not trivial. We next describe a computation of the Tate pairing by using the proposed distortion map. We also see that this type of curve is equipped with a simple quintuple operation on the Jacobian group, which leads to an improvement for computing the Tate pairing. We further show the Ate pairing, a variant of the Tate pairing for elliptic curves, can be applied to this curve. The Ate pairing yields an algorithm which is about 50 % more efficient than the Tate pairing in this case.

paper_title.en: On Carmichael numbers up to 19 decimal digit

description.ja: Carmichael numbers up to 10^<16> were known by the computation of R. G. E. Pinch [10](1998). We have computed the numbers up to 10^<19>. We let C(x) denote the numbers of Carmichael numbers less than x. Then C(10_<17>)=585355 [8](2002), C(10^<18>)=1401644 and C(10^<19>)=3381816. The result C(2.5・10^<18>)=1987866 was computed twice. Our method is constructive and similar to that of R. G. E. Pinch [9](1993). We used personal computers with Pentium 3-0.73～1GHz and UBASIC86 32bit version 8.8f for DOS/V.
description.en: Carmichael numbers up to 10^<16> were known by the computation of R. G. E. Pinch [10](1998). We have computed the numbers up to 10^<19>. We let C(x) denote the numbers of Carmichael numbers less than x. Then C(10_<17>)=585355 [8](2002), C(10^<18>)=1401644 and C(10^<19>)=3381816. The result C(2.5・10^<18>)=1987866 was computed twice. Our method is constructive and similar to that of R. G. E. Pinch [9](1993). We used personal computers with Pentium 3-0.73〜1GHz and UBASIC86 32bit version 8.8f for DOS/V.
